Bacterial Blight.Symptoms: Angular, dark green, water-soaked lesions on leaves that later turn brown and dry. Black lesions on stems, branches, and bolls. In severe cases, plants show defoliation and boll rot.
Bacterial Blight.Favorable Conditions: Warm (25–30°C), humid weather with frequent rainfall and poor field sanitation.

Target Spot/Alternaria.Symptoms: Circular brown spots with concentric rings on leaves. Severe infection leads to premature defoliation. Boll infection causes poor lint quality.
Target Spot/Alternaria.Favorable Conditions: Warm, moist climate with prolonged leaf wetness.
Cultural: Maintain wider spacing to improve aeration

Powdery Mildew.Symptoms: White powdery growth on lower leaf surfaces, yellow patches on upper surface. Severe cases cause premature leaf drop and reduced boll setting.
Powdery Mildew.Favorable Conditions: Cool and dry conditions with high humidity during night.

Curl Virus.Causal Organism: Cotton Leaf Curl Virus (CLCuV), transmitted by whitefly (Bemisia tabaci)
Curl Virus.Symptoms: Upward curling of leaves, vein thickening, stunted growth, and poor boll development.
Curl Virus.Favorable Conditions: High whitefly population, warm and dry climate.
Chemical: Thiamethoxam 0.05% spray to control whitefly vector
Organic: Yellow sticky traps for vector monitoring
Cultural: Avoid continuous cotton cultivation in the same field

Healthy.Message: No treatment required. Maintain balanced fertilization and regular field monitoring. Encourage natural enemies like ladybird beetles for whitefly control.

Early Blight.Symptoms: Dark concentric rings on older leaves, progressing to yellowing and defoliation. Spots may also appear on stems and fruits.
Early Blight.Favorable Conditions: Warm temperatures (25–30°C), high humidity, and prolonged leaf wetness.
Organic: Trichoderma seed treatment or foliar spray
Cultural: Use drip irrigation to avoid leaf wetness

Late Blight.Symptoms: Irregular water-soaked lesions on leaves that turn brown and spread rapidly. White fungal growth on undersides of leaves. Fruits show firm, brown rot.
Late Blight.Favorable Conditions: Cool (18–22°C), humid conditions with frequent rains.

Leaf Curl Virus.Causal Organism: Tomato Leaf Curl Virus (ToLCV), transmitted by whitefly
Leaf Curl Virus.Symptoms: Upward curling of leaves, reduced leaf size, bushy stunted growth, poor flowering, and fruiting.

Mosaic Virus.Causal Organism: Tomato Mosaic Virus (ToMV) or Tobacco Mosaic Virus (TMV)
Mosaic Virus.Symptoms: Mottled, light and dark green mosaic on leaves, leaf distortion, stunted growth, reduced fruit set.
Mosaic Virus.Favorable Conditions: Mechanical transmission via handling, high aphid population.
Chemical: No direct chemical cure; control aphids using Dimethoate 0.05% spray
Cultural: Avoid tobacco use by handlers (TMV risk)

Septoria.Symptoms: Small, circular, water-soaked lesions on older leaves with dark brown margins and grey centers, leading to leaf drop.
Septoria.Favorable Conditions: Warm and humid weather with frequent rains.

Healthy.Message: No treatment required. Maintain balanced fertilization, mulching, and regular field monitoring. Ensure crop rotation and integrated pest management.

Northern Leaf Blight.Symptoms: Long, elliptical grey-green lesions on leaves that turn tan with age. Severe infection reduces photosynthesis and grain filling.
Northern Leaf Blight.Favorable Conditions: Moderate temperatures (18–27°C) with prolonged leaf wetness.

Common Rust.Symptoms: Small, cinnamon-brown pustules on both leaf surfaces. Severe cases reduce photosynthesis and yield.
Common Rust.Favorable Conditions: Cool, humid weather with cloudy days.

Gray Leaf Spot.Symptoms: Narrow rectangular grey to tan lesions between leaf veins, leading to premature senescence.
Gray Leaf Spot.Favorable Conditions: Warm, humid weather with extended leaf wetness.

Healthy.Message: No treatment required. Monitor fields regularly and follow integrated nutrient management. Encourage beneficial insects and adopt crop rotation.
